Promoting effect of reduction-oxidation strategy on the Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for propane total oxidation Sen Liang Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a 1 Ting Cai Investigation Writing – original draft Methodology b 1 Jing Yuan Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Project administration Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ Qin Tong Formal analysis b Xiaojun Hu Resources a ⁎ a School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai 201418, PR China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology Shanghai 201418 PR China aSchool of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai 201418, PR China b School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, PR China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University Shanghai 200240 PR China bSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 The co-authors contribute to the work equally. Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 is one of the most active and commonly used catalysts for environmental pollution control. However, the strong Co-Al interaction has seriously deteriorated their catalytic performance, and even affected the promotion effect of an effective improvement strategy. In our previous report, by reasonably adjusting the interaction, the reduction-oxidation (RO) strategy greatly improved its performance. Herein, by constructing a series of 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 of enhanced interaction, and treating them by RO strategy, we found that RO strategy improved the activity of all 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 for model reaction-propane total oxidation to varying degrees, but the improvement degree is closely related with the interaction strength. In 10CoAl-(500–700) with relatively strong interaction, the improvement was more remarkable than that of 10CoAl-(300–400) with weak interaction and 10CoAl-800 with strong interaction. The maximum reduced values of T50 and T90 are 129 °C and 162 °C over 10CoAl-700, 28 °C and 57 °C higher than that in our previous work. The biggest promoting effect of 10CoAl-(500–700) is the formation and redispersion of active cobalt species, where the latter contributed to the significant increase of 10CoAl-700. The more active Co species produced play a major role in increasing the activity of 10CoAl-(300–400), while weakening of Co-Al interaction slightly increases the activity of 10CoAl-800. This work provided deep insight into the performance improvement of catalysts for air pollution control, and will shed light on catalyst regeneration, design and optimization in the environmental field. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Promotion effect Reduction-oxidation strategy Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalysts Propane total oxidation VOCs removal Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction At present, volatile organic compounds (VOCs) seriously endanger human health and the atmospheric environment as one kind of the main air pollutants [1]. Various technologies, including recovery technologies and oxidative approaches have been developed to remove VOCs, among which catalytic total oxidation is considered to be one of the most effective pathways due to its high efficiency and low reaction temperature [1,2]. The commonly used catalysts for high-efficient total oxidation of VOCs are precious metal catalysts and transition metal oxide catalysts [1,2]. Due to comparative activities to precious metals and versatile surface modification possibility, transition metal oxide catalysts have attracted wide attention. Short chain alkanes are one of the most difficult compounds to activate and oxidize to CO2 and H2O because of their very high CH dissociation energy, where propane is usually used as the model molecule for developing high-performance catalysts in the catalytic total oxidation of VOCs [1,3,4]. Co3O4 is one of the most active transition metal oxides for catalytic total oxidation of VOCs due to its lower Co-O bond energy (159 KJ·mol−1) and easy activation of CH bond [5]. According to the literature report [6–10], highly active cobalt-based catalysts usually have high specific surface area, high reducing capacity and abundant oxygen vacancies, which are usually related to the particle size of Co3O4. Co3O4 with smaller size is more likely to produce defective sites and show better redox properties, and it is also easier to adsorb and activate reactant molecules, thus having higher catalytic reactivity. Generally speaking, the isolated Co3O4 nanoparticles tend to agglomerate with each other at high temperatures [11,12], deteriorating its performance. Loading the nanoparticles on a certain support is an effective method to obtain highly dispersed catalyst due to the dispersion of the support and the strong metal-support interaction [13–15]. Compared with pure Co3O4 catalyst, supported Co3O4 catalysts has higher anti-sintering and anti-deactivation ability [16], especially in industrial application of nano-Co-based catalysts. Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 is commonly used in the pool of candidate supported cobalt-based materials for the removal of VOCs, especially when it comes to the applications under actual environmental conditions since γ-Al2O3 has good mechanical properties and inertness [17]. However, because Co3O4 and γ-Al2O3 have the same spinel structure, the strong interaction resulted in the loss of active cobalt species on the surface, which seriously deteriorated the catalytic performance of Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 [18,19]. Recently, many methods such as introduction of noble metals [20], coating of γ-Al2O3 [21,22] with protective layer and post-treatment [16] have been proved to be the most effective to reduce and/or eliminate this negative influence, among which the post-treatment method have aroused widespread concern since it could promote the remarkable increase of supported cobalt-based catalysts in the reactions such as Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [23–25] and room temperature oxidation of CO [26], by adjusting the Co-Al interaction. In our previous research [27], we found for the first time the reduction-oxidation treatment of Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 greatly improved their catalytic performance for propane total oxidation. The reduction-oxidation treatment reduced the T50 and T90 of propane oxidation over 10%Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 by 101 °C and 105 °C, respectively, and even further improved the activity of 10%Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 during the on-stream stability test. Recently, we further found that the promotion of activity by this strategy on the activity is also influenced by the interface interaction in Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 to a great extent. The improvement degree of the activity by this strategy is closely related with the strength of the interface interaction. As far as we know, there are few systematic studies on the promotion effect of reduction-oxidation strategy on the activity of Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 with Co-Al interactions of different strengths. As a matter of fact, the detailed clarification of the physicochemical property evolution of Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 with interface interactions of different strengths by adopting an effective improvement strategy and the correlation between these evolved properties and enhanced activity is still unclear. Therefore, it is necessary to deeply understand the role of interface interaction regulation in improving the activity of Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 through an effective improvement strategy for the development of high-performance catalysts. Herein, in this paper, as a continuation of our earlier work [27], we mainly focused on probing the relationship between the activity improvement degree and enhanced physicochemical properties of the catalyst obtained before and after reduction-oxidation treatment, and emphasized the effect of this strategy on the adjustment of interface interaction, which will be responsible for activity increase of different degrees. A series of 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 with gradually enhanced interaction were constructed by calcined at increasing temperatures, and then they were treated by reduction-oxidation strategy, and their catalytic performance for propane total oxidation was evaluated. Further, the influence of calcination temperature on the modulation of physicochemical properties of 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 by regulating interface interaction and the subsequent catalytic activity promotion degree before and after reduction-oxidation treatment was investigated. It was found that the increase of Co-Al interaction in 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 resulted in the loss of active species and the aggregation of cobalt species on the surface, which gradually reduces their propane total oxidation activity, but the reduction-oxidation strategy improved the activity of all 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalysts to varying degrees by adjusting the dispersion and/or content of active species on the surface according to the interaction strength between them. This work provided deep insight into the performance improvement of catalysts for air pollution control, and will shed light on catalyst regeneration, design and optimization in the environmental field. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 10%Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 was prepared by the precipitation method. γ-Al2O3 was prepared by the calcination of pseudo-boehmite (Zibo Senchi Chemical Co., Ltd.) at 550 °C for 4 h. Briefly, a given amount of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was firstly dissolved in deionized water solution, the corresponding amount of γ-Al2O3 was added to it and stirred for 0.5 h. Then, a certain amount of Na2CO3 (1 mol·L − 1) was added drop-wise into an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O at 50 °C under vigorous agitation until the pH value reached 9.0, and continued stirring for 1 h. After aging and filtration, the precipitate was washed with deionized water until the pH value of the filtrate reached 7.0. The resultant precipitate was then dried at 50 °C overnight, followed by calcination at 300–800 °C in air for 3 h, the catalyst was noted as 10CoAl-T (T is the temperature in Celsius 300–800 °C). After calcination at different temperatures, the 10CoAl-T catalysts were reduced in 5% H2/Ar with a flow rate of 80 mL·min−1 at 500 °C for 3 h. Then, the oxidation treatment was carried out at 40 °C in a flowing air (50 mL·min−1) for 12 h following the reduction treatment. The obtained catalysts were labeled as 10CoAl-T-RO (T is the temperature in Celsius 300–800 °C). 2.2 Catalyst characterization Thermogravimetric (TG) curves were recorded on a LINSEIS STA PT1600 instrument in air at a rate of 10 °C·min−1 in the temperature range of 25∼900 °C. The nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured in static mode at −196 °C on an ASAP 2400 system. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of the samples were recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-RC powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40 kV and 100 mA). The diffractograms were recorded in the 2θ range of 10 to 80° with a 2θ step size of 0.02° and a step time of 0.1 s. Raman spectra were recorded on Via Reflflex Laser Raman instrument, equipped with a CCD (charge coupled device) detector. The excitation source was the 514.5 nm line of Ar ion laser. The laser power was set at 3 mW. All data or results of Raman spectra obtained from characterization tests are repeated basically three times. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of powder samples were recorded on a JEM-1400 instrument operated at 120 kV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HRTEM) images were taken on a JEM-2100 microscope that operated at 200 kV. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed with an Auto Chem II chemisorption 2920 analyzer (Micromeritics) using a thermal conductive detector (TCD). The sample (50 mg) was pre-treated by He (30 mL·min−1) at 250 °C for 1 h to remove surface contaminants. After cooling to 50 °C, 10% H2/Ar (30 mL·min−1) mixture was introduced and the temperature was raised to 750 °C at a rate of 10 °C·min−1. XPS measurements were made on a VG ESCALAB MK II spectrometer by using Mg Ka (1253.6 eV) radiation as the excitation source. Charging of samples was corrected by setting the binding energy of adventitious carbon (C1s) at 284.6 eV. Powder samples were pressed into self-supporting disks, loaded into a sub-chamber, and evacuated to 10−9 mbar maintaining 4 h, prior to the measurements at 25 °C. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation Catalytic total oxidation reactions were carried out in a continuous flow micro-reactor constitutes of a quartz tube of 4 mm of inner diameter and 400 mm of height at atmospheric pressure. One hundred milligram catalyst in the form of particles (0.2–0.4 mm) was placed at the bed of the micro-reactor. Then, the feed gas containing 0.1 vol% C3H8, 18 vol% O2, and balanced with N2 was passed through the reactor at a flow rate of 50 mL·min−1 with the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) being 30,000 mL·gcat −1 ·h − 1. Temperature was measured with a thermocouple located just at the bed thermal point of reactor. The effluent gasses were analyzed at a given temperature (to maintain 20 min) on-line by using a GC (Varian GC-450) equipped with FID (flame ionization detector). Catalytic activity was measured in the range 50–500 °C and the conversion data were calculated by the difference between inlet and outlet propane concentrations. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity of 10CoAl-T and 10CoAl-T-RO At the start of this work, a series of 10CoAl-T were prepared by the coprecipitation method by changing calcination temperature (Tc) from 300 °C to 800 °C, then reduced at 500 °C in hydrogen/argon atmosphere and oxidized at 40 °C (RO) in air, and 10CoAl-T-RO catalysts were synthesized. The precursor can be completely decomposed at 300 °C, and its mass will not change when the temperature rises to 800 °C from Fig. S1 (TG curve for the precursor of 10%Co3O4/γ-Al2O3). So 300–800 °C is chosen as the appropriate calcination temperature. The activity of 10CoAl-T and 10CoAl-T-RO catalysts for propane catalytic total oxidation were firstly evaluated and the results are shown in Fig. 1 (a) and (b) as a function of temperature. Further, their activity comparison results for these catalysts were also provided in Fig. 1(c) and Table 1 . For all of the catalysts, CO2 was the only product, and this is consistent with the previous observations [28,29]. As it shown in Fig. 1(a) and Table 1, the activity decreased in the order of 10CoAl-300 > 10CoAl-400 > 10CoAl-500 > 10CoAl-600 > 10CoAl-700 > 10CoAl-800 with Tc rise. From Fig. 1b, the activity curves of all 10CoAl-T-RO catalysts shifted to lower temperature, where the activity curves of 10CoAl-(300–600) are extremely close to each other, showing that the activities of 10CoAl-T are enhanced after RO treatment, but they vary in improvement degrees. 10CoAl-(500–700) has relatively larger decreased values (their ΔT50 and ΔT90 > 100 °C) than 10CoAl-T (T = 300, 400 and 800) (Fig. 1(c) and Table 1). The maximum ∆T50 and ∆T90 is on 10CoAl-700, 129 °C and 162 °C, and followed by 10CoAl-600 (120 °C and 137 °C), which are larger than 101 °C and 105 °C for 10CoAl-500 in our previous work [27]. From the results, it is seen that reduction-oxidation strategy is effective for the activity improvement of 10CoAl samples, irrespective of Tc, but the degree of improvement is closely related to Tc. The medium-high Tc zones (500–700 °C) are much more easily to accelerate the activity increase than low Tc (300–400 °C) and high Tc (800 °C) by RO treatment. The results are very interesting. As we know, the Co-Al interaction is greatly correlated with Tc, and the increasing Tc will intensify the Co-Al interaction. The above results indicated that reduction-oxidation strategy exert different regulation effect on the Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 with Co-Al interactions of different strengths. 3.2 Catalyst characterizations of 10CoAl-T and 10CoAl-T-RO 3.2.1 BET surface area, pore size distribution and pore volume To clarify the different regulation effect, we then carried out the detailed characterizations for 10CoAl-T and 10CoAl-T-RO samples. The BET surface areas (SBET) of 10CoAl-T and 10CoAl-T-RO are summarized in Table 2 . The SBET of 10CoAl-T fall in the range of 122–175 m2 ·g − 1. When Tc is below 600 °C, 10CoAl-T (T = 300∼500) has a similar specific surface area of 165–175 m2 ·g − 1, which are close to SBET of γ-Al2O3 [30]. Then it decreases to 142 m2 ·g − 1 for 10CoAl-600, and further decreases to 133 m2 ·g − 1 and 122 m2 ·g − 1 for 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800, respectively. These are related to the sintering of Co3O4 in the samples at high temperature. The pore volume of 10CoAl-T (T = 300–700) is similar, ranging from 0.34 to 0.37 cm3·g − 1, but the pore volume of 10CoAl-800 greatly decreased to 0.29 cm3·g − 1, which is because of the Co3O4 sintering at high Tc and the formation of CoAl2O4 resulted by the strong Co-Al interaction. Similarly, the pore size of 10CoAl-T (T = 300–600) is 6.9–7.7 nm, while the high Tc leads to the agglomeration of Co3O4 in the pore channels, and thus the pore size of 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800 slightly increases to 8.4–8.7 nm. The SBET of the treated samples is practically the same as that of the original 10CoAl samples except 10CoAl-600-RO. After RO treatment, the SBET increased from 142 m2 ·g − 1 of 10CoAl-600 to 185 m2 ·g − 1 of 10CoAl-600-RO. This may be due to the formation of smaller particles of Co3O4 after RO treatment in 10CoAl-600-RO. Additionally, the pore volumes of all the treated samples, 0.29–0.36 cm3·g − 1, are also close to that of the original 10CoAl-T samples. But the average pore size varies to different degrees. Compared with their corresponding 10CoAl-T samples, the pore size of 10CoAl-300-RO slightly increased and the pore size decreased for 10CoAl-(400–700)-RO. Only 10CoAl-800-RO still kept the same pore size as 10CoAl-800. According to our previous study [27], the decrease for the pore sizes in 10CoAl-(400–700)-RO is due to the redispersion of cobalt species in the pores during RO process, while the cobalt species sintering at higher reduction temperatures may cause the cobalt species to migrate out of the pores, making the pore size of 10CoAl-300-RO slightly increase. The detailed demonstration will be shown in the following characterizations., 3.2.2 TEM Their TEM images and the average particle size of Co3O4 are presented in Fig. 2 and Table 2. The elemental mapping images of 10CoAl-600 and 10CoAl-600-RO are also provided in Fig. S2 to illustrate the distribution of Co3O4 on the surface of γ-Al2O3. From Fig. 2A(a), large quantity of cobalt species is distributed on the γ-Al2O3 support for all 10CoAl-T samples, but Co3O4 particles grow and/or agglomeration with the increase of Tc. As Tc increases from 300 °C to 500 °C, the Co3O4 particle size grows obviously, especially when Tc is higher than 600 °C, the cobalt species in 10CoAl-600 are sintered, and the agglomeration of 10CoAl-700 catalyst is obvious. When Tc is increased to 800 °C, the Co3O4 particle size does not increase obviously. From Table 2, 10CoAl-300 has the smallest particle size, with an average particle size of 4 nm. When Tc rises to 500 °C, the particle size increases from 6 nm in 10CoAl-400 to 8 nm in 10CoAl-500. When Tc increased to 600 °C, the catalyst obviously agglomerated, and the particle size of 10CoAl-600 increased to 13 nm. Roasting at 700 °C made the Co3O4 particle size grow to 16 nm. As CoAl2O4 was newly formed in 10CoAl-800 (further confirmed by the following analysis), its particle size did not further increase, reaching 13 nm. After RO treatment, the cobalt species are still dispersed uniformly on γ-Al2O3 for 10CoAl-(300–600)-RO samples but they agglomerated seriously in 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO (Fig. 2B). Except for a few Co3O4 dispersed on the surface of the carrier, most of them exist independently in 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO. Although agglomeration still exists after RO treatment, its dispersion is relatively more uniform than that before RO treatment. Comparing the average particle size of the catalyst before and after RO treatment, it can be found that, except for 10CoAl-300-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO, the particle size of the 10CoAl-(400–700)-RO catalysts decreased in different degrees. Especially the 10CoAl-600, after RO treatment, its particle size decreased from 13 nm to 9 nm (Table 2), followed by 10CoAl-700-RO, and its particle size decreased from 16 nm to 13 nm. The change extent of particle size in 10CoAl-400-RO and 10CoAl-500-RO is small, decreasing from 6 nm to 5 nm and from 8 nm to 7 nm, respectively. However, both the particle sizes of 10CoAl-300-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO increased. The reduction at 500 °C made the derived surface cobalt species on the surface of 10CoAl-300-RO agglomerate, and the strong Co-Al interaction prevents the surface Co3O4 from redispersing on the surface of 10CoAl-800-RO. 3.2.3 Phase composition (XRD) XRD technique was used to determine the crystalline structure change of the 10CoAl-T samples before and after RO treatment, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . From Fig. 3a, all the 10CoAl-T samples mainly presented the spinel diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS 01–074–2206) [31] and Co3O4 (JCPDS 76–1802) [32]. And the diffraction peaks ascribed to Co3O4 are intensified much with Tc elevating from 300 °C to 700 °C and then weakened obviously at 800 °C. The intensified peak from 300 °C to 700 °C indicates an increase of the particle sizes of Co3O4 in 10CoAl-(300–700) samples. The damped peak for 10CoAl-800 could be due to the formation of CoAl2O4. According to the literature [22], Co(NO3)2·6H2O can interact with γ-Al2O3 to form CoAl2O4 by calcining in air at above 800 °C. Further, it is observed that the color of 10CoAl-800 is sky-blue, completely different from the military green of 10CoAl-(300–700) samples (Fig. S3). It is reported that the color of CoAl2O4 is sky-blue [33], so a part of Co3O4 was converted to CoAl2O4 as a result of strong Co-Al interaction and this weakened the diffraction peaks for Co3O4 in 10CoAl-800. As Co3O4 and CoAl2O4 have the same cubic spinel structure and similar diffraction peak positions, there may still be Co3O4 in 10CoAl-800. All of these will be verified further by the following characterizations. After RO treatment, the characteristic peaks of Co3O4 become weakened and at the same time two new peaks turned up at 42.8° and 62.1° ascribed to CoO (PDF#48–1719) for 10CoAl-(300–600)-RO, especially the characteristic peaks of Co3O4 have almost disappeared and even very weak new peak at 44.3° attributed to Co for 10CoAl-(300–500)-RO [27]. Additionally, with temperature rise from 300 °C to 600 °C, the peak intensity of CoO weakened. 10CoAl-700-RO presented greatly damped peaks of Co3O4 with no new CoO peaks observed, and there is no obvious change of peak intensity of Co3O4 for 10CoAl-800 and 10CoAl-800-RO (Fig. 3b). These indicate that surface Co3O4 could be reduced to CoO and/or Co for the samples calcinated at Tc ≤ 600 °C, and the reduction degree gradually decreased with calcination temperature rise. The surface Co3O4 in 10CoAl-(300–500)-RO could be completely reduced to CoO/Co and only part of surface Co3O4 in 10CoAl-600-RO could be reduced to CoO at 500 °C. When Tc is above 700 °C, the surface Co3O4 could not be reduced, but its particle size decreased for 10CoAl-700-RO. It is difficult to make surface Co3O4 in 10CoAl-800-RO change at 500 °C. It was reported that [34] a metal oxide with larger particle size is harder to be reduced than that with smaller particle size. 10CoAl-600 has a much larger particle size of Co3O4 than 10CoAl-(300–500) samples, which made the 10CoAl-600 more difficult to be reduced than 10CoAl-(300–500). The 10CoAl-700 could not be reduced because of its maximum particle size (Table 2) and strong Co-Al interaction. But as there is no CoAl2O4 formation in 10CoAl-700, Co3O4 re-disperses on its surface. When Tc is 800 °C, the Co-Al interaction is too strong to reduce and re-disperse surface Co3O4. The changes could also be observed from the pictures of 10CoAl-T-RO. From Fig.S3 and Fig.S4, except for 10CoAl-800 and 10CoAl-800-RO, the color of other samples changed obviously before and after RO treatment, which indicated that RO treatment made the catalyst composition change obviously. 3.2.4 Raman To explore the surface structure change, the Raman spectra of the 10CoAl-T and 10CoAl-T-RO are displayed in Fig. 4 . Co3O4 exists in all 10CoAl-T samples from the intensive Raman shifts at 190, 475, 520, 615 and 677 cm−1 in Fig. 4a, which is in accordance with XRD results. And with Tc increasing from 300 °C to 700 °C, the Raman vibration peak at 677 cm−1 gradually becomes asymmetric. In addition, besides the characteristic peak of Co3O4, there is a shoulder peak at the wavelength of ∼709 cm−1 in the spectrogram, which belongs to the CoxOy-Al2O3 mesophase [35,36] formed by Co-Al interaction. There are no diffraction peaks attributed to CoAl2O4 (198, 412, 480, 519, 619, 690, and 753 cm−1) [37] in 10CoAl-(300–700). All these show that the main components of cobalt species in 10CoAl-(300–700) are Co3O4 and CoxOy-Al2O3 phases, and with the increase of Tc, the Co-Al interaction is enhanced. The Raman spectrum of 10CoAl-800 is obviously different from that of 10CoAl-(300–700), in which the intensity of Raman characteristic peaks attributed to Co3O4 spinel structure decreases obviously, while the intensity of Raman characteristic peaks attributed to CoAl2O4 (198, 519 and 690 cm −1) increases. In agreement with XRD results, part of Co3O4 in 10CoAl-800 interacts strongly with γ-Al2O3 to form CoAl2O4. Raman spectrum analysis proved that Co-Al interaction in 10CoAl-T increased with the increase of Tc, and the inert CoAl2O4 phase was formed in 10CoAl-800. After RO treatment, Co3O4 spinel (190, 475, 520 and 677 cm−1) are still present for 10CoAl-(300–800)-RO (Fig. 4b). However, the band (709 cm−1) ascribed to CoxOy-Al2O3 interphase disappeared for 10CoAl-(300–500)-RO and weakened for 10CoAl-600-RO. There was no obvious change of Raman shift of 709 cm−1 (CoxOy-Al2O3) for 10CoAl-700-RO. In the Raman spectrum of 10CoAl-800-RO, obvious characteristic peaks attributed to CoAl2O4 can be still observed at the positions of vibration peaks of 198, 519 and 690 cm−1. Further, as Raman bands of CoO (484 and 691 cm−1) overlaps with those of Co3O4 [38], the cobalt species on the surface may include CoO for 10CoAl-(300–500)-RO. Although no characteristic peaks for Co3O4 can be detected by XRD for 10CoAl-(300–500)-RO, the obvious Raman shifts on them indicate that there are Co3O4 species in them. Actually, the derived CoO in 10CoAl-(300–500)-RO could be further oxidized to highly dispersed Co3O4 during oxidation process. The disappearance or attenuation of CoxOy-Al2O3 in the Raman spectra of 10CoAl-(300–600)-RO showed that the interphase CoxOy-Al2O3 were completely or partly reduced and the strong interface interaction is weakened during the RO process, in accordance with XRD observation. When Tc is very high (700–800 °C), the interface interaction is very strong, and it is difficult to be reduced at 500 °C, so the Raman vibration peaks of CoxOy-Al2O3 and CoAl2O4 can still be observed in 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO, respectively. 3.2.5 H2-TPR H2-TPR profiles were further carried out to probe the reducibility of the 10CoAl-T and 10CoAl-T-RO catalysts, as shown in Fig. 5 a and Fig. 5b. Fig. 5b also provided the amplified H2-TPR profiles at 50–400 °C to clearly observe the reduction behavior of 10CoAl-T-RO. Table 3 listed the Tsur (the initial reduction temperature of surface Co3O4) and Tinter (the initial reduction temperature of interface) of all the samples. As shown in Fig. 5a, except for 10CoAl-800, two main reduction bands I and II were observed for 10CoAl-(300–700), among which band I is the overlapping band of two peaks. According to literature [39], γ-Al2O3 could not be reduced in this temperature range, so all reduction peaks in the spectrum are attributed to the reduction of cobalt species. The bands I and II are ascribed to the reduction of large surface Co3O4 to metallic Co via transient CoO formation and interfacial CoxOy-Al2O3, respectively [22,26,37]. The existence of CoxOy-Al2O3 confirmed the Co-Al interaction for 10CoAl-(300–700), which is consistent with Raman analysis. Further, with Tc increasing from 300 °C to 600 °C, the band I moves to higher temperature, and Tsur increases from 200 °C to 290 °C (Table 1), which is due to the increase of the particle size of Co3O4 on the surface of the catalyst, in accordance with the characterization results of XRD and TEM. And as shown in Fig. 5a, in 10CoAl-300, the two-step reduction attributed to Co3O4 can be clearly seen, while in 10CoAl-(400–600), the characteristic peaks attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and the reduction of CoO to Co overlap as a reduction peak, which indicates that the Co-Al interaction in the sample increases with the increase of Tc. Particularly, when Tc is further increased from 600 °C to 700 °C, Tsur is greatly increased to 536 °C, which is 246 °C higher than that of 10CoAl-600. Since the particle size of Co3O4 increased slightly from 13 nm for 10CoAl-600 to 16 nm for 10CoAl-700, the significant increase of reduction temperature may be related to stronger Co-Al interaction in 10CoAl-700. Further, the band II attributed to CoxOy-Al2O3 reduction for 10CoAl-T also shifted to high temperature direction with Tc increasing from 300-400 °C to 500–600 °C and then 700 °C, indicating that the interface interaction gradually increases with Tc increase. Particularly, when Tc rises from 500-600 °C to 700 °C, the band II moves to much higher temperature, rising from 514-524 °C to 660 °C, which indicates that there is much stronger Co-Al interaction in 10CoAl-700 compared with 10CoAl-600 and 10CoAl-500. 10CoAl-800 has no reduction peak under 750 °C, which is related to very strong interaction between cobalt species and γ-Al2O3 in the catalyst. On one hand, the strong interface interaction makes a large number of cobalt species generate inert CoAl2O4. On the other hand, it increases the reduction temperature of surface Co3O4. TPR results are consistent with XRD and Raman results. As shown in Fig. 5b, after RO treatment, the H2-TPR behavior of 10CoAl-T-RO samples changed greatly. Compared with 10CoAl-(300–700) samples, there are still two reduction bands I and II in the H2-TPR profiles of 10CoAl-(300–700)-RO, but except for the band I in 10CoAl-300-RO, they shifted to lower temperature direction. As shown in Table 3, Tsur (band I) of 10CoAl-(400–700)-RO showed different degrees of decrease except that 10CoAl-300-RO presented a slight increased Tsur than 10CoAl-300 (211 °C vs. 200 °C). All the Tinter (band II) of 10CoAl-(300–700)-RO are lower than that of their corresponding 10CoAl-(300–700). By comparing H2-TPR profiles of 10CoAl-800 and 10CoAl-800-RO, it is found that band I and band II newly turned up in the RO treated 10CoAl-800-RO sample. The lower temperature shift or new turn-up of band I and II shown in 10CoAl-T-RO samples indicated that RO treatment in a certain degree decreased the particle size of surface Co3O4 and weakened Co-Al interaction of 10CoAl-T. But the reduction in a higher temperature of 500 °C made Co3O4 in 10CoAl-300-RO grow. From Table 3, one can find that 10CoAl-(500–700)-RO has much bigger decrease value of both Tsur and Tinter than 10CoAl-400-RO. It shows that reduction at 500 °C is more beneficial to decrease the particle size of surface Co3O4 species and weaken the interfacial interaction of 10CoAl-T obtained at higher Tc of 500–700 °C than 400 °C. This is mainly because, on one hand, the surface Co3O4 and the interface CoxOy-Al2O3 are reduced to form highly dispersed Co3O4 species, on the other hand, the derived cobalt species are easy to grow up. These two effects will cancel each other, and made 10CoAl-400 present a much lower decrease degree. Compared with 10CoAl-400, it is easier for 10CoAl-300 to make derived cobalt species grow in large quantities by reduction at 500 °C, so 10 CoAl-300-RO has a higher Tsur than 10CoAl-300. Reduction at 500 °C greatly adjusted the composition and interface interaction of cobalt species on the surface of 10CoAl-(500–700)-RO, but did not make the cobalt species grow up, thus making them have greater changes. At the same time, besides band I and band II, new reduction peaks appeared in the H2-TPR spectra of 10CoAl-T-RO samples. These new reduction peaks were named as α, β and γ, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5b. According to XRD and the results in our previous work [27], the emerging peaks α, β and γ are attributed to the reduction of highly-dispersed surface Co3O4, the reduction-derived CoO and the newly-derived interfacial species (named as CoOx) caused by the reduction of CoxOy-Al2O3 species. CoO (peak β) mainly comes from the reduction of Co3O4 on the surface and/or CoxOy-Al2O3 species on the interface. CoOx (peak γ) mainly comes from the reduction of CoxOy-Al2O3 species on the interface. As shown in Fig. 5b, when Tc is lower than 600 °C, the reduction peaks β and γ appear in the H2-TPR curves of 10CoAl-(300–600)-RO catalysts, but there are no β and γ in 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO. The results showed that surface Co3O4 and/or interface CoxOy-Al2O3 species can be reduced to CoO or CoOx species in 10CoAl-(300–600)-RO treated at lower Tc, but these species are difficult to be obtained in 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800 calcined at 700–800 °C by RO treatment. These are in accordance with XRD and Raman results. The highly-dispersed surface Co3O4 (peak α) mainly comes from the redispersion products of unreduced Co3O4 and/or the oxidation products of CoO generated by reduction. This part of Co3O4 is much smaller than that of the original surface Co3O4 (band I). From Fig. 5b, except 10CoAl-300-RO, all the other samples 10CoAl-(400–800)-RO showed peak α in their H2-TPR profiles. It shows that reduction treatment regulated the composition and distribution of the surface Co3O4 species of 10CoAl-(400–800)-RO. As surface Co3O4 and/or interfacial CoxOy-Al2O3 could not be reduced to CoO in 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO, the highly-dispersed surface Co3O4 species in these two samples could be re-dispersion products of un-reduced Co3O4. That is, RO treatment decreased the particle size of Co3O4 in 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO by weakening their Co-Al interaction. Although RO treatment made surface Co3O4 and/or interfacial CoxOy-Al2O3 species in 10CoAl-300 reduced, it also increased the size of newly generated Co3O4 particles in 10CoAl-300 samples. Thus, there is no peak α in the H2-TPR pattern of 10CoAl-300-RO. 3.2.6 XPS XPS was used to examine the surface element composition and chemical states of the cobalt species. As it shown in Table 3, the surface n(Co)/(n(Co) + n ( Al)) ratio for 10CoAl-T decreased with Tc increasing from 300 °C to 800 °C. It is 0.17 and 0.15 for 10CoAl-300 and 10CoAl-400, respectively. And with Tc increasing to 500 °C and 600 °C, the n(Co)/(n(Co) + n ( Al)) ratio decreases slightly to 0.12 and 0.11, respectively. Further increase of Tc to 700 °C and 800 °C resulted in a significant decrease of the n(Co)/(n(Co) + n ( Al)) ratio to 0.06. The results show that the Co3O4 particles grow up with Tc rise. The aggregation of cobalt species on the surface and the strong CoxOy-Al2O3 interaction made 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800 have such low cobalt species content on the surface. This is consistent with the results of TEM and H2-TPR. From Fig. 6 a, all the Co2p XPS spectra of 10CoAl-(300–800) presented two intense doublet bands at 780.3–781.7 eV and 795.4–797.5 eV with weak satellites accompanying each of doublets at higher binding energies. In the spectrum of 10CoAl-300, the intense doublets are present at 780.3 eV and 795.4 eV, and corresponding satellites at 789.7 eV and 805.0 eV, respectively. With Tc increasing from 300 °C to 600 °C, the Co2p XPS spectra shifts slightly to higher binding energy integrally with the increase of Tc from 300 °C to 600 °C and then greatly shifted to much higher binding energy when Tc is 700 °C and 800 °C. According to the literature [40,41], the doublets and the presence of a pair of weak satellites at higher binding energies of 10CoAl-(300–600) were ascribed to the characteristic spectra of Co3O4. Slight movement of binding energy shows that the interaction strength of Co-Al increases slightly with the increase of Tc from 300 °C to 600 °C. This result is consistent with the conclusion of H2-TPR. The similar characteristic peaks of Co3O4 in 10CoAl-(300–600) catalysts show that the cobalt species in the samples with Tc lower than 700 °C are mainly dispersed in the form of Co3O4 on the surface of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6a, the binding energy of Co2p3/2 on 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800 are 781.2 eV and 781.7 eV, respectively. Especially, for 10CoAl-800, its binding energy is much close to 782.0 eV of the CoAl2O4 [42]. The spectrum of 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800 moves to high binding energy much more than that of 10CoAl-(300–600), accompanying the enhanced peak intensity of Co2+ satellite at 786.8 eV, indicating that calcination at 700 °C and 800 °C resulted in a very strong interaction between Co3O4 and γ-Al2O3, forming CoxOy-Al2O3, especially CoAl2O4 for 10CoAl-800. Therefore, the Co-Al interaction in 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800 is much greater than that in 10CoAl-(300–600). Additionally, for 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800, the characteristic peak strength of Co2p attributed to Co3O4 decreased greatly, indicating that the content of Co3O4 in the samples decreased greatly, which was caused by the strong interaction by high-temperature calcination. The surface cobalt species in 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800 are the combination of a small amount of Co3O4 and interface species. After RO treatment, the surface n(Co)/(n(Co) + n ( Al)) ratios decreased from 0.17 of 10CoAl-300 to 0.16 for 10CoAl-300-RO, but 10CoAl-(500–700)-RO has an increased value compared with their corresponding samples, from 0.12, 0.11, 0.06 to 0.15, 0.13, 0.07, respectively (Table 3). 10CoAl-400 and 10CoAl-800 did not change before and after RO treatment. For 10CoAl-300-RO, the decrease of this value is due to the sintering of surface cobalt species by the weak-interaction at a high reduction temperature of 500 °C. The increase of this value for the samples obtained at 500–600 °C is attributed to the formation and redispersion of newly-derived surface cobalt species from the reduction of surface Co3O4 and interfacial species. The Co-Al interaction weakening in 10CoAl-700 after RO treatment, resulting in the redispersion of surface cobalt species, made the n(Co)/(n(Co) + n ( Al)) ratios of 10CoAl-700-RO slightly increase. The value of 10CoAl-400-RO does not change after RO treatment because of the offset between the increase caused by the complete reduction of interfacial substances and the decrease caused by the subsequent aggregation of particles. There are nearly no changes of these ratios for 10CoAl-800-RO, further indicating the Co-Al interaction is very strong. The Co2p XPS spectra of 10CoAl-T-RO still show the characteristic peaks ascribed to Co3O4. For 10CoAl-(300–600)-RO, there newly turned up the enhanced satellite peaks at binding energy = 786.8 eV and 803.3 eV ascribed to Co2+ with their corresponding 10CoAl-T samples, and the peak intensity at B.E. = 786.8 eV becomes weaker with Tc increasing from 300 °C to 600 °C. But no obvious enhanced peak of Co2+ could be observed for 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO samples. These demonstrated that surface Co3O4 and interfacial species could be reduced to CoO species for 10CoAl-(300–600) via RO treatment, and low Tc is more beneficial for reduction of these cobalt species, while the surface Co3O4 and/or interfacial species could not be reduced to CoO for 10CoAl-700-RO and 10CoAl-800-RO. For the samples calcinated at 700 °C, the binding energy of Co2p3/2 decreased from 781.3 eV in 10CoAl-700 to 781.0 eV in 10CoAl-700-RO, and the characteristic peak intensity of Co3O4 in the Co2p XPS spectrum of the latter is enhanced, demonstrating that the strong interface CoxOy-Al2O3 interaction in the catalyst was greatly weakened and the species of Co3O4 on its surface increased after the RO treatment. Combined H2-TPR characterization, RO treatment made the Co3O4 species redispersed on the surface by greatly weakening the interfacial interaction. For 10CoAl-800-RO, there was no obvious movement of the main doublet bands of Co2p XPS spectra, but its Co2p3/2 satellite peak became weakened and slightly shifted to lower binding energy, indicating that the Co-Al interaction could not be reduced or greatly weakened by reduction at 500 °C, but a small part of surface Co3O4 could be redispersed on the surface of 10CoAl-800-RO. The surface Co3O4 amount is much less than that in 10CoAl-700-RO from its relatively weak Co3O4 characteristic peak. 4 Discussion Combined with the above characterization results, with the increase of Tc from 300 °C to 800 °C, the Co3O4 on the surface is agglomerated, and the interaction is gradually strengthened, which leads to the formation of interface species, and reduces the content of active species, thus reducing its catalytic activity, while the RO treatment promoted their activity improvement to different degrees mainly by the redispersion of active Co3O4 species and generation of new cobalt species, which depended on their strength of Co-Al interaction. Fig. 7 is the correlation diagram of physicochemical property changes and activity changes before and after RO treatment with calcination temperature. Obviously, BET is not the reason for their activity improvement from Fig. 7a that SBET of the catalysts did not change significantly before and after RO treatment except 10CoAl-600 in which the big SBET increase are produced by the great decrease of particle size of Co3O4. From Fig. 7a, the catalyst particle size of 10CoAl-600 decreases the most, followed by 10CoAl-700 and then 10CoAl-400 and 10CoAl-500. The particle size did not change for 10CoAl-800 and even increased for 10CoAl-300. From Fig. 7b, both 10CoAl-500 and 10CoAl-700 showed the maximum ΔTsur and ΔTint, followed by 10CoAl-600, and then 10CoAl-400 showed a very small decrease of Tsur and Tint, while Tsur of 10CoAl-300 even slightly increased. From Fig. 7c, the migration value of Co2p3/2 XPS spectra of 10CoAl-(300–600) to higher binding energy is the largest, while the Co2p3/2 binding energy of 10CoAl-700 decreases the most (−0.3 eV) after RO treatment. The Co2p3/2 XPS did not migrate for 10CoAl-800 after RO treatment. At the same time, 10CoAl-(500–700) shows a large added value of n(Co)/(n(Co) + n ( Al)), which did not increase when Tc=400/800 °C, and even decreases when Tc = 300 °C. Both the formation of new cobalt species and re-dispersion of cobalt species led to the above results. The surface Co3O4 and CoxOy-Al2O3 species could be reduced to CoO/Co at 500 °C and then oxidated to Co3O4 when Tc≤600 °C, but they could not be reduced when Tc = 700 °C and 800 °C. That is, there are new active cobalt species formation for 10CoAl-(300–600) samples, but not for 10CoAl-(700–800) because of their much strong interaction. Further, the newly formed active species in 10CoAl-(500–600) couldn't grow due to the moderate interaction, but they further grow up for 10CoAl-(300–400) (the Δn(Co)/(n(Co) + n ( Al) is −0.01 for 10CoAl-300 and 0 for 10CoAl-400, respectively in Fig. 7c and Δsize and ΔTsur is 2 nm and 11 °C for 10CoAl-300 in Fig. 7a and 7b) due to their weak interaction, though much more new species are produced by RO treatment (large migration of Co2p3/2 XPS spectra in Fig. 7c). So the newly generated active species and the re-dispersion of active species by moderate Co-Al interaction jointly promoted the activity of 10CoAl-(500–600), generating a great activity improvement of them. For 10CoAl-(300–400), the apparent activity is the comprehensive result of the increase of activity produced by new active species and the decrease of activity caused by particle growth. The final result is that 10CoAl-(300–400) exhibited a small activity increase contributed mainly by the newly generated cobalt species. Due to the strong Co-Al interaction in 10CoAl-700 and 10CoAl-800, their surface Co3O4 and interface species couldn't be reduced and no new cobalt species formed after RO treatment. Their activity improvement is mainly attributed to re-dispersion of the active species caused by the weakening of Co-Al interaction. The drastic reduction of Tsur/Tint (Fig. 7b) and Co2p3/2 binding energy (Fig. 7c) of 10CoAl-700 after RO treatment reflects the weakening of the interface Co-Al interaction, which made it generate great redispersion of Co3O4 on the surface (Fig. 7a), promoting its great activity increase. As CoAl2O4 (because of very strong Co-Al interaction) species formed in 10CoAl-800, its physicochemical properties did not present obvious changes (Fig. 7a and 7c), and the Co-Al interaction is only slightly weakened (H2-TPR result), which made the activity of 10CoAl-800 increased slightly. Thus, the stronger interaction in 10CoAl-800 made it generate a lower weakening extent than 10CoAl-700, which made 10CoAl-700 show greater activity improvement than 10CoAl-800. Therefore, RO treatment could improve the propane total oxidation activity of 10CoAl-T (T = 300–800) with different interactions, but the biggest increase is the samples obtained at moderate calcination temperature (500–700 °C). The lower and higher calcination temperatures (300–400 °C and 800 °C) couldn't greatly improve the activity because the interaction between them is too weak and strong. Combined all the above analysis, the new active cobalt species and re-dispersion of cobalt species by moderate interaction regulation jointly promoted the catalytic activity of 10CoAl-500 and 10CoAl-600, while the redispersion of active cobalt species caused by weakening of Co-Al interaction is the main reason for the great increase of the activity of 10CoAl-700. After RO treatment, the activity of 10CoAl-300 and 10CoAl-400 increased slightly, mainly because the interface CoxOy-Al2O3 species was reduced to a large extent, which resulted in new active species. The weak weakening of Co-Al interaction makes the activity of 10CoAl-800 slightly increased due to its very strong interaction. 5 Conclusion In summary, the Co-Al interaction in 10CoAl-T increases with the increase of calcination temperature, resulting in the loss of active species and the aggregation of cobalt species on the surface, which gradually reduces the activity for propane total oxidation in 10CoAl-T. However, the reduction-oxidation treatment increased the propane oxidation activity of 10CoAl-T, which was closely related with their interaction strength of Co-Al. Among them, the 10CoAl-(500–700) with medium Co-Al strength increased the most. The maximum ∆T50 and ∆T90 value are 129 °C and 162 °C on 10CoAl-700, respectively, 28 °C and 57 °C higher than that in our previous work, and 10CoAl-600 presented the largest reduction degree, 34.8% for T50 and 34.1% for T90. Then comes with 10CoAl-(300–400) with weak Co-Al interaction and 10CoAl-800 with very strong Co-Al interaction. More active Co species play a major role in improving the activity of 10CoAl-(300–400), while slight weakening of Co-Al interaction slightly increased the activity of 10CoAl-800. The biggest increase of activity of 10CoAl-500 and 10CoAl-600 is due to the new active cobalt species and re-dispersion of active cobalt species caused by the moderate interaction regulation, while the re-dispersion of active cobalt species caused by the greatly weakening Co-Al interaction is the main reason for the significant increase of activity of 10 CoAl-700. coredata.dc:description: Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 is one of the most active and commonly used catalysts for environmental pollution control. However, the strong Co-Al interaction has seriously deteriorated their catalytic performance, and even affected the promotion effect of an effective improvement strategy. In our previous report, by reasonably adjusting the interaction, the reduction-oxidation (RO) strategy greatly improved its performance. Herein, by constructing a series of 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 of enhanced interaction, and treating them by RO strategy, we found that RO strategy improved the activity of all 10Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 for model reaction-propane total oxidation to varying degrees, but the improvement degree is closely related with the interaction strength. In 10CoAl-(500–700) with relatively strong interaction, the improvement was more remarkable than that of 10CoAl-(300–400) with weak interaction and 10CoAl-800 with strong interaction. The maximum reduced values of T50 and T90 are 129 °C and 162 °C over 10CoAl-700, 28 °C and 57 °C higher than that in our previous work. The biggest promoting effect of 10CoAl-(500–700) is the formation and redispersion of active cobalt species, where the latter contributed to the significant increase of 10CoAl-700. The more active Co species produced play a major role in increasing the activity of 10CoAl-(300–400), while weakening of Co-Al interaction slightly increases the activity of 10CoAl-800. This work provided deep insight into the performance improvement of catalysts for air pollution control, and will shed light on catalyst regeneration, design and optimization in the environmental field.
coredata.dc:title: Promoting effect of reduction-oxidation strategy on the Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalysts for propane total oxidation
